Articles.Content: Any thoughts on who's going to the moon next? I had a thought of the chinese landing next to one of the US's landing spots and tearing down the flag and wrecking all the stuff we left behind >.< I personally hope they don't do that(Plus why would they do that XD) I personally think the EU will be the next to live their footprints.

That won't happen, but I could see the EU or China landing on the moon next. They obviously would avoid former landing spots. There was a controversy about the Lunar X Prize landing near it, and NASA suggested they didn't land within a certain area.

I wonder why would they ask others to avoid those sites. It would certainly put an end to all those conspiracy theories. One way or the other.

I wasn't aware that ESA had a plan to land a human on the moon in near future.

China or North Korea (NK with its Kerbalesque approach) would be my guess.

Okay, I'll weigh in here.

Whilst I'm a science teacher, I am also trained in History[1]. We have a unique opportunity with the Apollo landing sites - namely, those sites will be preserved in pristine condition forever unless they are hit by a meteoroid (which is highly unlikely) or disturbed by human activities.

For that reason, I believe that it is imperative that those sites remain as undisturbed as possible. Remember that even the slightest error could compromise the integrity of the sites. Therefore before any program (national or corporate) tries to visit one of the landing sites, I'd say it is critical that they formulate a plan of how to do so without any potential of disturbing the site. And one thing to remember is that even the footprints (at least at the Apollo 11 site) have historical significance.

[1] As far as I am aware, I am the only person to have ever graduated from my university with a Bachelor of Arts in History, minoring in Chemistry and with a diploma of Education.

Sure it's important to preserve Appolo 11 site. But there are others where that significance diminishes.

If you designate every spot a one time landing site, you'll run out landing zones.

Preserve one or two, let the others be visitable.

That's fairly similar to NASA's proposed approach. They want serious exclusion zones around the Apollo 11 and 17 sites. They are a little more relaxed about visits to other Apollo landing sites, but ask people to remember that they have some experiments that are still operational, and also request that people "look but don't touch".

On the other hand, they've presented a list of objects that could be examined as part of a serious research program into Apollo 15, and have demonstrated that you could achieve a lot of worthwhile observations with a rover that was equipped only with an HD camera.

Details of their proposal:

http://www.nasa.gov/pdf/617743main_NASA-USG_LUNAR_HISTORIC_SITES_RevA-508.pdf

If anyone goes back to the moon it'll undoubtedly be the Chinese, largely for flag-waving purposes. They're the only folks with a serious moon programme, and with the political will and resources to make it happen.
